headline: Evolution of San Sebastian's Coastline
text: In this timeline, we will take you through the many changes that have occured to the coastline of San Sebastián throughout history

headline: The City is Officially Chartered
text:
Though the area had been inhabited for thousands of years, San Sebastián was first chartered in 1181 by King Sancho VI of Navarre.

This was done by the ruling monarchy to encourage emigration to the area, while also promoting the growth of local industry, primarily fishing.

headline: The Coastline is Heavily Fortified
text:
Though there existed a humble castle atop Mount Urgull since the late 1100s around when the city was officially chartered, by the 1500s it was in a sorry state and was unlikely to be useful defensively. Because of this, King Charles the 5th mandated its restoration and upgrade, through several projects that spanned from 1520 and continued throughout the rest of the 16th century.

The mount continued to be fortified sporadically for the next 400 years, until it was sold to the city and demilitarized in 1924. Though no longer operational, Castillo de la Mota is now a public park.

Many other coastal fortification besides those on Mount Urgull have been built along the coastline of San Sebastian, with one in nearby Zarautz, and one on Mount Ulia, named the Monpas Battery (which we covered in a previous feature story).

headline: The Opening of The Igeldo Funicular
text: On August 25th, 1912, the oldest funicular in Basque Country was opened. Still in use today, these wooden tracks will take you to the top of Mount Igeldo.

headline: The Zurriola Bridge was Constructed
text: This beautiful landmark was built to cross the river Urumea into Gros.
